byline.contributor: Javier C. Hernández reported from Beijing, and Floyd Whaley from Manila. Michael S. Schmidt contributed reporting from Washington, and Yufan Huang contributed research from Beijing.
byline.original: By JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and FLOYD WHALEY

abstract: Philippine Supreme Court votes, 10-4, to allow American military to station troops and weapons at bases in Philippines; decision will likely heighten tensions between United States and China, which is seeking to establish itself as dominant power in region by building military facilities in South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: Under the decision, the United States will be allowed to station troops and weapons at crucial bases, decades after Manila lawmakers expelled American troops.

headline.main: Philippine Supreme Court Approves Return of U.S. Troops
headline.print_headline: Philippine Supreme Court Approves Agreement on Return of U.S. Forces

snippet: Under the decision, the United States will be allowed to station troops and weapons at crucial bases, decades after Manila lawmakers expelled American troops.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
